commentBody:
T 25.15
Best 20.16
Average 35.16

No look up.

Got really annoyed by the puzzle from 4/15/2012.  Why would anyone build a museum in the fashion of a crossword for the movie “Titanic”?
SIGIL was a new one for me.  But I did come up with a new term:  PROM rock.  "Stairway to Heaven" anyone?  (I'm showing my age.)
dream theater is a bad band!
What a beautiful puzzle!
Wowzer. This puzzle is Thursday-worthy. Feeling fulfilled.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/07/26/sunday-july-27-2025/#ny
126 across made me giggle. Thanks for a very entertaining and challenging puzzle, Mr. Kugelman.

Amazing construction. I can’t even imagine the brain power it took to come up with 11-letter anagrams like that!  My first thought at 24A was that it had to be wrong. My kids are GENERATION X and *they* aren’t middle-aged … oh, wait, they actually are! How did that happen??

Do anagrams MOLT from one to the other?
Do they transmogrify as does MULCH?
Whichever, it’s gotten so I can see them coming a mile away. It was good they were in pairs so we had a fighting chance.

Today’s temporary wrong answer:
“Desperate avoidance of fame”:
CLOUD CHASING
This was something. No idea how hard this must have been. Thanks Wordplay for some help. Great puzzle. Thanks.
Okay, applause
Chapeau, monsieur Kugelman!
53A: I was pleased to see a non-food nod to Captain Q.

Great puzzle! Only 4 minutes off my best Sunday time this week with no lookups. Fun theme and reasonably challenging clues with not many naticks, except for Mainer, newbs and craig. I got stuck with noobs instead of newbs for a while after the rest of the puzzle was filled.
Can someone enlighten me on the cluing for Mainer? Google has revealed that Downeaster is an Amtrak line from Massachusetts to Maine, but I’m failing to understand how that ends up as Mainer. 
Otherwise very fun; hats off to the creator. I’m dipping my toes into crossword creation and it’s so much harder than solving one :p
I've seen 126-across before, maybe on Reddit or Tumblr. I bet the constructor saw the same post as me and that became their seed entry.
Fuhgeddaboudit.

Fun one! I print it out so I didn't see any dividing line but it wasn't necessary. Got stuck on SIGIL and PROG, but I got there eventually, grumbling along the way. Brilliant anagramming and cluing. Thank you, John Kugelman.
Le sigh.

A baffling grid until the puzzle got underway, then it was cheeky and fun.  A new-to-me fill: SIGIL (needed the column for that one), and a lot of oldies cleverly clued (Money for money—pretty cool).  Hopped around a lot and watched the anagrams surface, one after another. 

I applaud your convoluted puzzle constructing genius, John Kugelman, and now I am a genius too for solving this one.  Thank you!

Fast and fun. Sped through this one, although it wasn't always easy. I probably made a mistake going down the west side instead of solving across like I usually do, but I got two-thirds the way down and then switched over to the east half and almost immediately picked up on the anagrams, which then helped me finish the ones I'd already started, which left 126, which was also solved quickly. Liked the cluing as well, no matter who came up with or polished them.

For 43D I was ready to put "Yensid" as Mickey's boss until I saw the length of the answer, so I had to go with his vocation, rather than his name. I had posh for too long at 2D before LUXE, and TOrah before TOTEM briefly at the bottom, and there were a couple I had to wait for crosses to finish, but it still ended up being one of my faster Sundays.

Thanks, John!

24 Across

“Forgiving middle-aged dads for their dad jokes, says”?

Answer: “ Exonerating Generation X”.

I’m sorry.  In defense for all bachelors from the Gen X generation, you have to be dads first in order to make this work.  Otherwise, our jokes can just be seen as regularly terrible.
I'm aware of sigils only because of repeated references to them in Game of Thrones.

So, while anagrams are on the table, I’d like to share one I like that I recently ran into:

A DECIMAL POINT – I’M A DOT IN PLACE





Et tu, emu.

Whoa Nellie dropping in, big pants and down jacket:

HOORAY, I SOLVED IT!  |  OH, I SORTED IT, YO!
Cute theme. Worked well. Now, if I can just make it safely through Thursday, I'll have my best month ever with only one failed puzzle for the month
95% was pretty easy. 5% was impossible.

Well that's two times I've had to reveal a square in the last week or so. Not loving this journey for me. HARRUMPH!  😏  

Once again, I was clipping along my merry way but could not come up with the cross of PRO? and SI?IL for the life of me. I certainly know that music but I didn't know it was ever called PROG. I looked it up later and see that it is short for progressive rock but all I could come up with at the time was the possibility of PROm, which really didn't make a lot of sense... although dancing to "We don't need no education" at one's prom might be kind of cool, though I never did go to prom. Not really my thing and I was a bridesmaid many times in that era, so I didn't lack for the big froofie '80s and early '90s frocks! Ooh, boy, I had some doozies!! 💃

Anyhow, it was my last square and I don't allow myself to run through the alphabet in the app, so when my taking a chance on PROm didn't work I did the reveal. 

And SIGIL is another word I just don't know. My voice to text just spelled it absolutely correctly on the first attempt, so it must be known well enough. 

I love the word SVELTE for some reason. It just rolls off one's tongue! Although, for the record, my voice to text does not spell that one correctly. 

Anyhow, lots of errands today so this puzzle was a good way to come home and chill out afterwards. 

Lastly, and this is important: We are GENERATION X!! We don't need no stinkin' EXONERATION!! Yeah!! (Insert Judd Nelson's iconic fist in the air.)✊😂✊
This one really made me laugh! Well done!

I have a strong opinion that if you are going to use anagrams in a crossword puzzle, there has to be a point to it (besides a cute revealer). This was a great example of it done well. The theme was funny and brilliant and clever, and the rest of the grid had a lot of lively answers also. And of course two Star Wars references, one Star Trek, one Harry Potter and Fantasia all tickle my fancy (your mileage may vary). Top marks from me.
loved it!

This puzzle was anagrammatically correct.  In my youth I sometimes imagined myself a CHECKMATINGCHICKMAGNET, but it was just my imagination running away with me.

I solved this fairly steadily, and the spent way too long searching for a typo.  Eventually I realized that a clock was not necessarily a clock radio and thus that amfm made no sense.  And neither did fROG rock as the genre for Pink Floyd.  Ah the perils of relying on crosses without checking the downs for accuracy. A fun and funny Sunday.
And they’re back for a second day in a row at 121D. This time as a pair!
Great!

I actually laughed out loud more than once when I figured sone of these out! I was also surprised how many of my “I guess it could be that, but I’ll wait before I enter anything” vibes turned out to be correct.

Funny, SIGIL was one of my gimmes -- probably coming from a lifetime of devouring fantasy novels. 

Read the clue for 95A as "in German" rather than " in Genesis" at first. Very confusing, that. 

113A I had AM_M as gimme but it's a toss up between F and P, so I left it blank at first... then 115D was _ROG and I got to imagine fROG rock before I sighed and put in the more boring P...

A delightful puzzle! 😲😊 And I learned a new word — “sigil”. I’ve never seen it before, and not just in the context of crossword puzzles. Thankfully, as an amateur musician, I know my prog rock, so i didn’t have to cycle through the letters of the alphabet on the NYT app to get the letter “g” 🙂 The phrase “clout chasing” is also new to me, although since it’s described as “modern lingo”, I wasn’t surprised. As a member of Generation X, I hope that I’ll be exonerated for that 😉

Biggie Smalls is the name I gave my 1/2 inch to 3/8 inch socket adapter.
You can probably guess what Smallie Biggs is.

Great to see INXS in there today, as yesterday (Saturday in Australia), their song Never Tear Us Apart was voted in at #1 in the Hottest Australian Songs of all time. https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-07-26/inxs-never-tear-us-apart-hottest-100-australian-songs-all-time/105576582 The song is the unofficial anthem for my Australian Rules football team Port Adelaide, so it was a pity it couldn't help them defeat crosstown rivals Adelaide in the Showdown last night. A huge 133-35 loss :'( Some background on the "World's Greatest Music Democracy": https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/triple-j-new-hottest-100-australian-songs-poll-1236000674/

Finally, a Sunday PB. Annual flyby’s paid.

(Sorry for the dad joke.)

All the time I was solving I was thinking, "I bet this is another puzzle that's going to be blasted because it's too easy."  (Not that I didn't have an error to find after completion.)  But at no time did I ever feel I was going to be totally stuck, with only seven uncrossed answers, four of which turned out to be wrong.

*That* to me, is a hard puzzle.

But as uncalibrated as my hard-ometer seems to be, I wasn't sure.

I'm kind of relieved that the early voting doesn't seem to be putting it in the Monday category.
Geez Louise! I gotta take a French class to do the crossword? Y’all could have clued most of these differently. End rant. It was still a blast.

im gonna call iffy on 56D.  the force cannot be taught.  it is the chi of the star wars universe.  it simply is and abides in all things.  now...teaching how to USE the force?  great. MANIPULATE it?  fine.  CORRUPT it, even?  groovy.  but teach the force itself?  doesnt work.
Hey! Who are you calling middle aged!?!?

Ooh, anagrams! Impressive to have such long ones, and incorporated into a crossword puzzle, too. This may have been the first John Kugelman puzzle I enjoyed. Yeah, yeah, I know he's one of the beloved constructors of this community, but his previous grids never resonated with me. I'm a weirdo 🤷.

The fill was mostly enjoyable. It wasn't all smooth sailing for me though.

I had NooBS rather than NEWBS, which seemed sensible, but made that area of the grid unsolvable for me, as I did not understand Down Easter and the 100 DC thing (I assumed it would be an address of some important place in Washington, starting with an S. Senate, maybe? But I just could not think of how to abbreviate Senate to 4 letters). In the end I looked up SENS, and only then was I able to deal with that area.

I don't get SENS, really. What is it short for, exactly? Senators? But how can Senators, rather than the Senate, have an address? I'm so confused 🤪.

The crossing of OST(E)R and S(E)LIG was a natick, for me.

What's an Army BRAT? I know I could google it, but I can also have AI solve the puzzle, yet I don't, so please humor me.

Of course, as is usually the case on Sunday, as I filled the final square I got the dreaded "So close, suckaaaahhh" pop-up. I CBA to flyspeck a huge grid so I checked the puzzle. It turned out some wild guesses I had in one corner of the grid were wrong.
Very nice. For me, the anagram theme was exposed by ITSA ME MARIO. After that, it was lots of fun to discover the other four.

No exoneration needed for these delightfully dad joke-y anagrams—whatever generation you may be! They all hit just the right balance between silly and stretchy. It seems creating  these must have been a daunting endeavor, indeed.

In college, as a NEWB at chess, I had occasion to play a game with a German gent who I think styled himself a CHECKMATING CHICK MAGNET. Due to my ignorance of the standard openings and gambits, my moves were thoroughly idiosyncratic, and served to flummox my more knowledgeable opponent, who slunk away in ignominy. A most satisfying victory for me, who was not feeling the magnetism! 😉

Thanks for the puzzle, Mr. Kugelman!
Mickeys boss is not SORCERER, it's Yen Sid. Specifically Disney spelled backwards, and modeled after Walt Disney's own mannerisms. Great puzzle, but that clue hint feels extremely wasted.
Really fun today. Loved the anagrams, especially the Italian (or Italian-American?) one.

In fact, INXS’ Never Tear Us Apart was just yesterday voted number one on Triple J’s Hottest 100 of Australian Songs Triple J is the national youth(ish) radio station run by the national broadcaster, the ABC (Here that stands for _Australian_ Broadcasting Corporation, of course 😁 They have various TV and radio stations, including for instance Double J, which is for people who used to listen to Triple J when they were younger - e.g. me 🤣) Every year in Jan they run a Hottest 100, as voted by listeners. (Any song released in the previous year is eligible, not just Aussie songs.) Periodically they do variations on the Hottest 100 like The Hottest 100 of All Time or this Aussie only version. If anyone’s interested, the full list is here https://www.abc.net.au/triplej/countdown/hottest100/1-100
Can't go by Biggie Smalls without a mention of the Biggie Smalls - Thomas the Tank Engine mashup... https://youtu.be/PXa59Wjgrxc Let's just say Tipper Gore would put a sticker on this one.
Up two hours early, with work-stress insomnia. Thanks, 1D! In a puzzle far, far away: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hEcjgJSqSRU&list=RDhEcjgJSqSRU&start_radio=1 (Lovin' that telekinetic guitar!)

The G in SIGIL was my last square. It was a guess with PROG which was also a guess.

Calling Generation X "middle-aged" was a bit shocking since I'm older than Gen X. :)

ITS A ME MARIO was a teeny bit racially-insensitive but overall the puzzle was fun.

Raced through this puzzle, got the first theme answer and said "Oh, anagrams," then proceeded to complete the grid at a dizzying pace. Then I got to 115D. PROM rock seemed like a perfectly good answer, and since I didn't know a SIGIL from a simil (which sounded wrong anyway), I just went with it. Glad I don't worry about streaks. But just one little letter between failure and greatness. Sigh.

John has had 13 Times puzzles in the past two years, which is impressive enough, but 11 of them have been Sundays.  Sundays are beasts to make – you not only have to come up with a worthy theme, but you have to design a grid to accommodate it, fill it, and come up with clues for some 140 words!

John not only does this ably, but he injects humor and inventiveness as well.  Here’s an example from today’s puzzle that incorporates both – [Apt name for a narcissist?] for MIMI.  That’s an answer seen well more than 100 times in the major crossword outlets, almost always clued to a famous Mimi in real life or the character in Rent or La Bohème, but never with the narcissism angle before.  Plus, the clue made me smile.

It’s a little thing, that MIMI clue, but also a big thing.

I’ve learned over time that when I see John’s name atop a puzzle, I know I’m in for the unexpected and for a dip into levity, and I plunge in with great expectations.  And, as with today’s puzzle, I end up well rewarded.

Just want to thank you for that, John.  You are a one-of-a-kind and a pro.
I am consistently amazed and humbled at the cleverness of these late week puzzles.  Bravo and thank you to all of you constructors.

Wow. Just Wow! Can't even imagine what it must have taken to come up with those 5 pairs of 11 letter anagrams and then manage to find a way to clue them together. Just amazing. Oh, and a tough workout for me, but finally catching on to the trick was a big turning point. And that made for one really enjoyable workout. Perhaps appropriate puzzle find today - another one with an unusual trick. A Sunday from January 16, 2005 by Damon J. Gulczynski with the title "Pledge of allegiance." The 'reveal' (or hint) in that puzzle was a grid spanning answer: ALLFORONEANDONEFORALL And a couple of theme clues and answers in the puzzle: "Klutzy dog's habit" DROPPINGTHEBONE "Bathroom on wheels" ROLLINGSTALL And some other theme answers: PONEBEARER HEIRTOTHETHRALL TONEINTHESADDLE HONEOFFAME GALLWITHTHEWIND And there were more. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/16/2005&g=88&d=A .....

It's odd how some puzzles fall into the "correct" place in the easy-to-hard continuum (as aggregated in the xwstats.com numbers) for an individual, and some do not.  And the reasons may not be apparent to that individual solver.

Yesterday, I mentioned that I did not find the puzzle "Very Easy", as xwstats labeled it, although I still finished a bit faster than my Sat. average.  I had to keep moving around the grid, looking for footholds, and although nothing stumped me that much, it didn't seem like a "Very Easy" puzzle to me, despite the stats and the anecdotal evidence in others' comments.

Yesterday (i.e. Fri. night), I was not especially tired, and had no obvious reason not to have breezed through the puzzle.  I just didn't.

Today (actually last night), I had just gotten home from a visit to my kids and other relatives in Philadelphia, where I had no opportunity to rest, and helped my nephew assemble some furniture and other physical tasks, as he and his family are also moving soon.  After a heavy restaurant meal with the family, we headed back home and got there around 9:45, with me at the wheel.  

I should have been quite tired as I opened the crossword and began solving.  However, I was able to put in a time 22% faster than my Sun. average, and a minute or so faster than the median time listed on xwstats.  

Didn't comment on this last night, since I was quite tired by the end.  Tired enough not to finish watching the Mets game.

Who can figure how that happens?

Cute anagrams, and proper capitalization of Outback.

@ Steve L (Since, of course, EMUS only nest in one specific Subaru model.) ;-)

Chewy but fun. As usual, my brain is incapable of analyzing anagrams, so it was a bit of a slog filling via crosses.

Spent some time looking for my error, to find I had spelled SAL in French (SeL). 
Could someone explain SELIG and MAINER to me please?

My daughter, my son and I live in different places and team up on the NYT Crossword. It takes some of the burden off of the grueling ones and it is a really nice family thing to do. We are on a streak of 244 in a row and chat every morning. Sometimes, to keep the streak going, and faced with a toughie, we are still at it late at night.  Thank you NYT!
Now THIS is what I came here for today. An excellent puzzle and a great workout. Thanks John!

I have mixed feelings about PROG rock.  I love Pink Floyd; I like  Genesis, ELP, and ELO.  Rush, Kansas, Styx?  They're OK in small doses.  I'd never heard of Dream Theater until today.

But here's my (serious, earnest) question.  What's "progressive" about PROG rock?
Loved this puzzle!
I found the anagrams a bit forced and cringey but that's just me. Nice fill and I admire the construction

Those of us who come back to the "Comments" at the end of the day to see where we stand in the "Reader Picks" list, I guess we're CLOUT CHASING?

Guilty as charged.  At least now I have a name for the phenomenon.

C'mon, friends, give me those "Recommends".
I'm with Rich in Atlanta; wow. How  you guys put these things together mystifies me.  ( That's not what a technocrat is BTW).

Having had the luxury ( and absolute pleasure )
of constructing with John,
I am in awe of his standards.

His high bar for fill, 
adherence to symmetry,
and willingness to scrap a week’s work 
(or three…hypothetically?)
to avoid a sub-standard corner 
or even a single word,
is (a smidge) frustrating 
and *insanely* impressive.

Kugelman ain’t lazy. And man, does it show.
Solid, heavy-duty construction, every single time.

Thank you John!
Sunday puzzle rockstar!
The Italian American anagram clue and answer is one of the best things I’ve seen in a crossword. Is this the same Gary Larson who does the far side comics?

This was a bit chewy for me and not in a bad way. Yes SIRREE nicely done 🎉. 
Loved 27A. He still has a car dealership in my area which is how he started back in the 1960s. My dad had several cars from SELIG Ford. Have Bud to thank for bringing baseball back to Milwaukee and building a stadium with a roof. 👏⚾️
One of the best Sunday puzzles ever. Thank you John, very clever.

And with that, I made 8 gold stars in a row. Not my first time, but it’s not a regular occurrence. 

I enjoyed it, and appreciate the work that went into constructing it. But I have to disappoint Francis and say this was too quick for me. I was expecting to have this to work on from time all day, but I finished it in 45 minutes. YMMV. That being said, after the magnum opus that was 3 weeks ago (“Escape Room”), I’m afraid it will be hard for a Sunday to live up to heightened expectations.
Thank you for 126, made my day 😁
I moved almost a thousand miles away from my family in November, to downeast ME, and it was all worth it just to get 53A on my first pass
A nice Maine connection in this puzzle - my home town of Brunswick, Maine has a delicious food truck called Taco the Town.

HOLY MOLEY!!! I'm a little slow sometimes. Everybody's commenting on the anagrams and I'm thinking yeah, that word sounds familiar. Then it dawned on me that the two answers had all the same letters! Looks like it's gonna be a DUH kind of day 🥴
This is by far my favorite puzzle of my 2,554 solved NYT crosswords. Thank you and congratulations John Kugelman!

I recognized SIGIL from playing "The Room" which is a gorgeous and elegant computer puzzle game (its actually in The Room 2 or 3, not sure which). There's a code required to progress and the answer is SIGIL which until today I thought was a made up word! So now it makes more sense.

(If you like puzzles and haven't discovered The Room, it's a treat. Totally worth the $5 or whatever it costs to install on your tablet or computer. I go back and play them over and over again)
CHECKMATING CHICK MAGNET will have me chuckling all day.

I didn't really "get" the pairs (no bold dividing line shows up if you print the puzzle) but I didn't care too much...just slogged along until I winkled out the entries.  Of course, in "best for last" fashion, Our Mr. Kugelman had the semi-baffling 126A.  
Where I was partially stumped was at the cross of 132A and 115D.  If it had been a radio, AMFM and FROG would have been plainer, but I NEVER know any rock genres/bands/'artists' and I had three possibles...I did opt for the G, so I have a shiny A PLUS for today's puzzle.  
Now I need to look up "caravel" and I can finish my pancake with fresh fruit and maple syrup.  Ah, Sunday Breakfasts!
So fun!

TIL MARIO’s first name is “ITS AME”.  
It’s not certain that all pyramids are tombs.
Am I the only one here who knows what SIGIL is?
Very clever anagrams.

Relatively new to crosswords and crossword construction. My reaction was WOW! The best puzzle I've seen! But so discouraging, makes me think I'll never get a Sunday Puzzle published if this is the standard

I really need help here. 
I seem to be alone in finding those long clues impenetrable, even with almost all the crossers.
Not knowing Larry Page and Sergey Brin, only knowing 'street legal' as a Dylan album, absolutely no idea about the chess clue, and I can't begin to comprehend the 'famous Italian' clue. 

Previous posts have alerted me to the famous Italian being a cartoon character (!?), but who is the actress? What does MARISATHOMEI mean?

I got most of the other clues (except the one about Easter: I assumed a religious festival), SELIG, RAMEN (why eat it in your bedroom?) and OSTER. 
Feeling a bit dim.

[Bud in Cooperstown] was on the tip of my tongue and I didn’t really know why. Then I just went with my gut and slapped SELIG in there. It was only after I finished the puzzle that I realized why I knew it 🤦🏼‍♀️ I lived north of Milwaukee from 2016-2020 and he was inducted into the Hall of Fame while I lived there, not to mention his time as commissioner... Definitely a head slap moment on my part 🤣 I’m actually visiting WI now as my daughter just finished her annual two weeks at Camp Minikani. Her group travelled up to the Apostle Islands of Lake Superior and canoed to several of the islands, camping on each one they visited. What an amazing experience! There were several clues in the grid that reminded me of my daughter, including 9A for BARNUM, 36A muppet ROSITA, 42A SASSES and 18D for MANI 🤣🤣🤣 If I never again hear the soundtrack for The Greatest Showman, it will be too soon 🥴 I still hear their screeching little voices trying to sing the songs 🙉 
Anywho, we’re off to visit the other two mentioned screeching voices before heading off to the East Coast to visit the in-laws. Happy Sunday Crosslandia!
Nice Sunday puzzle, just a minute off my best. Off to the archives to see what sort of mischief I can get into. Have a great day.

The trouble with NYT crosswords is the number of Americanisms relevant only to Americans.
As an international newspaper it should rely less on obscure baseball questions or American personalities.
Any puzzle with Biggie and anagrams is a hit with me, even though I feel that two Star Wars references are two too many.

126-Across was definitely what inspired this puzzle.  Truly saving the best for last.

Great puzzle!  Or in the spirit of many of the clues, un puzzle merveilleux!
Loved the cross of two great showmen at 9D/A

Any puzzle with Marissa Tomei in it is okay by me. And James Dohan's Scotty!* Who has the single greatest line in the original Star Trek series. https://youtu.be/sKLyXjMT07I?si=E8loYLV-UJIoBMwO *I also enjoy Simon Pegg's Scotty.

A fun, anagram-filled Sunday puzzle of an unusual 22 x 21 size. This went pretty fast, but at the end it took some time to figure out the answers around the word BIOME. I'm not sure if the heavy black lines were really needed here.

One small natick for me that ruined an otherwise smooth fill by making me go through every single answer in the grid and, eventually, ask for help.  I have never heard of "prog" rock, nor "frog" rock which I had originally -- because both AM/PM and AM/FM apply to many clocks, including the one I have in my bedroom.  I didn't think about it, and could not figure out where my error was.  With the benefit of hindsight, AM/PM makes more sense, but there was nothing in either crossing that made me think what I had originally was incorrect.

SIGIL was a gimme from Game of Thrones.   And I am from Milwaukee, as is Bud SELIG.  So another gimme.  I caught on to the anagrams from STREET LEGAL - LET'S GET REAL along with the puzzle title of Arranged Marriage.
Back to back French clues crossed with a proper noun is diabolical
I thought rookies are noobs.  I never saw it as news.  Took me a while to correct.  Nice puzzle.
Incredibly clever theme with great cluing. Really enjoyed this one.
Delighted to see Dream Theater make an appearance in today's puzzle!
This puzzle is a masterpiece! Loved it. Well done :)
I'm a little disappointed my comment presumably got deleted. Obviously not saying people had to agree, but I don't think I was out of line.

The title should have been "Rearranged Marriages".

Change my mind.
Brilliant! Wonderful to see anagrams again. Thank you, setter.

For some reason I got all of the left sides of the themers first except for 126A. She was the last thing in the grid to fall, which surprised me because she is one of my favorite actors and her last name appears in crosswords fairly frequently (for good reason). But it was a satisfying end to my solve.

Got nothing until well into my first pass through the acrosses, but the grid was a steady, appropriately chewy fill after that. Was vexed I couldn't think of the third eponymous scientist at 104A (because I've studied those guys enough), but thought of the inventor at 130A immediately.
126A made me stop and kiss my fingertips.

Finished the right half first for whatever reason, then did the anagrams to give me the footholds on the left half.

CLOUTCHASING? Learn something new every other day....
TIL that "It's'a me, Mario!" is an anagram for Marisa Tomei and it made my day!

"Mickey Mouse's boss"

He has a name. Master Yen Sid did not put up with Mickey's shenanigans to be reduced to just "sorcerer"

Another late remarkable puzzle find. A Thursday from August 12, 2010 by Barry Boone. Here are the theme clues and answers" 17a. "See 38 across" MORSECODE 73A. "See 38 across." SOS And then... 38 across: "73-across in 17-across" 9 rebus entries, all of them three letters: (DIT)((DIT)(DIT)(DAH)(DAH)DAH)(DIT)(DIT)(DIT) Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/12/2010&g=12&d=D ...
Much fun. Gonna try and slip 99 across into a conversation.

Fun puzzle; I love anagrams. Solved this in near-record time for a Sunday. (I think it helped that I do the down clues first.)

Unrelated: Could whoever decided to insert a giant "Have a moment? Play these games" ad for other NYT Games in the middle of this column please reverse that decision? Thank you.
Enjoyed the puzzle, finished in good time, but somehow solved everything without noticing the anagrams! D’oh!
alway amazed by extended anagrams, plus good cluing!
Zipped through this one at an almost PB rate.  Love anagrams, and clueing at 126 was great and chuckle-inducing.  Felt like a win today.

I *loved* this puzzle! I got just enough of the crossings pretty easily to keep me at it and even though I had to look up some of the trivia clues (Star Trek, Muppet character, s****), I was tickled to figure out all the paired anagrams myself. Really fun and a delightful Sunday puzzle!

I had a good time with this one. I randomly wound up filling the entire right half with almost nothing on the left side, which made for an interesting visual that seemed weirdly fitting for the theme. I guessed it was going to be long anagrams, which are always entertaining, and sure enough I had a lot of fun working out the left half of each pair.

This is perhaps my favorite NYT crossword of all time. Ok, I am admittedly biased as it contains my favorite band (Dream Theater) and favorite TV show (Seinfeld) of all time. I also just happen to be driving past Gainesville as I write this. The cluing was excellent and the theme is [chef’s miss]. Bravo John!
Very clever and not an easy solve for me. I had GOTHS instead of GAULS for the longest time and also COLA instead of SODA. I knew about loofah and luffa, but loofa was a surprise.

One more puzzle find. This one likely appropriate for many us on some days. A Tuesday from September 6, 2016 by Timothy Polin. The theme answers: The first ones paired with each other: THEMS THEBREAKS And the other theme answers: ANDSOITGOES WINSOMELOSESOME QUESERASERA THATSLIFE And the last one: IQUIT Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/6/2016&g=50&d=A Probably re-post this tomorrow. ...
I've done 100's of these and never commented. But this puzzle deserves special recognition. Well done.

Spent the day weaving through the Maine countryside, starting, coincidentally, on the fringe of Downeast (btw, a real Mainer says Maine-uh) and dabbling on this puzzle—a neat challenge and I feel pretty good having cued in on the theme fairly quickly. Lotsa fun—thank you!
A couple of friends and i often get together to do the Sunday...this one was huge fun!!  Grazie, John!!
Awesome puzzle! Almost felt breezy, even on a Sunday! The anagrams were a joy, and I was tickled by nearby clues like ORCA/OKRA and AMPERE/THOMAS EDISON. If only every Sunday felt like this!

I laughed out loud when I wrote "IT'S A ME MARIO"
So stupid, but so funny...🤪

A bit of a tangent, related to the clue for 97D.  The most famous speaker of the line "Bah Humbug!" is Ebenezer Scrooge, of course.  But do you really know what he meant by that?  One of the 19th century definitions of the slang term "humbug" was related to "insincerity," and THIS is what he was railing against (he didn't just hate Christmas, as he's often portrayed on screen).  Because Scrooge had no Christmas spirit in his heart at the beginning of the story, he assumed that those displaying it (through acts of charity, generosity, merriment, etc.) were just faking it to make themselves look better.  After I read that in a modern introduction to the story, it really cast his character in a whole new light and made his transformation at the end more understandable.
haven't read all of the comments, but has anyone mentions that ARRAnGEd has most of what it takes to anagram mARRiAGEs?
I do t get the Holy Women clue for Stes? Also, what's a Selig? Thanks in advance
Much respect to the constructor! I knew a lot of the fill but the theme entries eluded me until I gave in and read the column. Wow, amazing.

I cocked an eyebrow at the clue for ORCA. A black and white hunter to be sure, but why is it "black-and-white"? The hyphenation gives the impression that "black" and "white" are parts of a single term--suggesting perhaps that the hunter is after black-and-whites. Like maybe my aunt Myrna at a deli. 

Since Myrna didn't fit and ORCA did, I wasn't misdirected for long, but I question whether that misdirect was entirely kosher.

This was a fun puzzle!

If you’re visiting SF, check out the Interval at Long Now. In addition to being an excellent bar and coffeehouse, you get a sneak peek into the library of the Long Now Foundation. Thinking about the big picture is best done over a cocktail while you stare at the ocean.
Okay nobody judge, I haven’t been cross wording for very long 🙈 but this was my first Sunday completed in under an hour!
Ok, THAT was adorable! Mwah!

I'm pretty close to cancelling my sub after this puzzle. The Sundays lately have been full of mediocre fill but this one had some incorrect clueing. Technocracy is almost always defined as governance by experts - something Brin and Page are not - and the less common definition - technical expert managers - would make sense if Brin was any kind of manager at this point, having stepped down as CEO of Alphabet in 2019. Additionally, Biggie Smalls was one of the Notorious B.I.G.'s pseudonyms, but was not his actual name nor his stage name.

It worries me that Will thought this was elegantly clued. It just felt like a mess built on some decent anagrams. I guess being able to write software to make your puzzles is what counts for talent these days.
Really superb anagrams and a fun puzzle overall. Favorite in a long time. Or “long now”?

Maine is known as Down East, thus someone from Maine could be a Mainer.

@Ruben Sandwich

People from the southern/coastal area of Maine are said to be from "down east", so a "down easter" would be a MAINER.

@Paul ah, I see! I thought that was counterintuitive at first, but turns out it comes from sailors traveling down the prevailing winds out of the southwest to go east up the Maine coast, hence the term Down East. Fascinating!
Not sure why searching Down East didn't take you here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Down_East

@Ruben Sandwich people from Maine call themselves MAINERs. People from away call us Mainiacs, one of the many ways we can identify people from away 🤣

I, myself, am from away. Even though both of my parents were born here, I was not, and will forever be from away, even though I have lived here for more than half my life!
Calling someone from Maine a Mainer seems very normal to me. It's the Down Easter moniker that feels obscure...

@Andrzej They are tools - socket wrenches. The wrench has a square flange that the different sizes of hex sockets attach to. If you have a wrench with a 1/2 inch square flange, but a socket with a 3/8 inch recess, then you use an adapter to join them.

@Paul

I used to try to be cool when teaching chemistry.  There is a concept when two or more reactants are weighed out to react to form products, one reactant will run out before the other(s).  That's called the limiting reagent, and everything else is "in excess".

When I'd do those problems on the board, underneath the reactants in excess, I'd write INXS.

Then I'd turn around to see how cool they thought I was.

It was very, very subtle, but I could tell they were profoundly impressed.  I could tell by their yawns and vaguely hostile espressions.

@Paul we used to joke about the "Never tear us apart" video, which featured Michael Hutchence and his romantic interest both with beautiful long dark curly hair, that it should be "they'll never tell us apart"

Are army brats bratty?

@Wes
@Andrzej

I only know three "army brats"  (navy brats, anyway).

They were my cousins.  All had difficult childhoods, with a lot of freedom and in Southern California, where a lot that can go wrong.

But that was eons ago.  They are all older than I am at 73.  

Today one is an elderly devoutly Christian lady.

One is a devout Jehovah's Witness.

The youngest one lived a totally depraved life, with a lot of street and a lot of drugs.  To the best of my knowledge, he was put eventually put into hospice, expect to die from decades of drug abuse.  Somehow he got walked away, and I'm not sure they ever found him.

So there's three examples.  I have no idea how to answer the question "are army brats bratty", from this sample group.

Andrzej,

Wait for Mean Old Lady to weigh in on Army BRAT.

@Andrzej
OooooKAY.  
The families of military folk (referred to as Dependants) usually move whenever and wherever the Army/Navy/AirForce/etc. assigns the individual serving, as long as the post is not in a danger zone.  (This is also true of the other families of different nationalities whom we came to know.)
My father was an artillery officer, and we lived in NC, West Germany (during Army of Occupation years), ARkansas, TX, Hawaii (Territory and then State!) and finally--in the year before he retired--Atlanta, GA, where we three kids were actually born.  
I do try to be polite about it, but I find the term BRAT offensive.  (Clue it some other way, Will!)  We prefer "Army kid."  It was not easy to be uprooted, and sometimes Dad was away for long periods--the longest being 16 months.
But I digress.
 We were  told how to conduct ourselves and expected to behave...and we did.  (In the vein of "May as well be hung for a sheep as a lamb," I rather wish I HAD been sassy, wild, and rough, dang it all!)
MOL, I know how you feel about the term, and awaited your comment, but see paragraph two. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_dependent

@Eric Hougland
Hah.  (First, I'm not a Mississippian--but it's where we're living now.  People even consider me to be "a Yankee."  Oh, the horror!)
    Barry got a chuckle, waving the red flag, so I have obliged by giving an expanded (but by no means thorough) definition...and critique.
     A huge T-storm yesterday evening left us with soggy soil (heavy clay) so it needs to dry out a bit.  I gave myself time off this morning, so the weeds are still out there, radiating guilt over my neglect.
(And I'm in mid-quilting on a 'commission' that I hope to complete this week...so there's that, too.)

Y'all stay safe in your new locale!  Tough weather this summer!

@Mean Old Lady

Thanks! I asked about brats being bratty because I found "army brats" kinda weird. It sounds so negative. I appreciate your post and position 🙂

@Barry Ancona
So, you prefer to accept wiki's claim over the lived experience of an actual person.....  You can also find sources that demonstrate the inferiority of non-white cultures and peoples.  
Kinky Friedman (who once ran for "Guv" of TX) grew up in the Texas culture that loved to hew to stereotypes about any minority group...so his band was "The Texas Jew-boys"...  in the same way that  groups sometimes embrace rude names they are called --in defiance and protest.  

While I can appreciate (now, anyway) living and traveling abroad, learning another language, and being exposed to impactful experiences, there were ways that military family life was difficult and even damaging to our partiicular family.

@Darcey O’D

😂  I'm glad you won.  You sound like the cooler person by far.

Still, I think you may be undervaluing your own inherent skill.

I'm no chess master, but it seems to me that anyone who can be flummoxed by unorthodox play must have some serious holes in their own game.

I mean, the whole point of the openings and such is to achieve strategic positions in the game:  solid center, good pawn structure, as many knights and bishops on powerful squares as possible, and rooks looking to take control of columns.

If one's opponent fails to do any of that, isn't the answer just to do that, and then find an attack from an invincible position?

I'd love to hear a chess lover comment.

@Francis

I think the issue with that opponent was that he overvalued his own inherent skill—which was what made beating him so satisfying! I haven’t played chess in years, with a couple exceptions, but I don’t think I ever showed any great aptitude for the game!

@Darcey O’D

Yeah, I think he overvalued his skill, too.  

And as far as not having played chess in years...my experience has been counterintuitive.  After a long gap of playing, the first few games felt very, very good, crisp, surprising myself with what I'd recalled.

So I'd play more, and study more, and as I did so, I got worse and worse.  I think it was paralysis by analysis.  

So I'd stop.  Repeat the cycle the next decade.

To me, he sounds like the kind of guy that knew the opening moves, but didn't know why.  

My guess is you (and I) would have been slaughtered by someone better, someone with a deep understanding.  Which he lacked.

@koty - Welcome to Maine! 

Care to share where downeast? (In the state, we generally define "downeast" as the coast east of Ellsworth... amd some consider THAT to include too much on the western end...)
@koty Can you explain 53A for me? It was the last to fall and I only got it on crosses!

@Catherine - In the US, "downeast" as a noun refers to Maine. In Maine, it refers specifically to the easternmost coastal region of the state. 

It derives from "down east" meaning a direction from days of sail, when one would head "down east" on the prevailing wind. 

Many people believe the Maine coast runs N/S -- but is is more E/W (really WSW-ENE) and in the days of square-rigged sail, going downwind in Maine meant heading eastward along the coast. 

I have seen many people claim they went as far north in maine as they could when they get to Eastport or Lubec. I live further north in latitude than either of those places, and almost half the state of Maine is further north than I am!

You should probably check out a map since I suspect those two towns won't mean anything to anyone who hasn't been to Maine.

@Tony R  The "Fr." in the clue indicates that the answer will be both in the French language and also abbreviated.  In French, the feminine form of "saint" is abbreviated "Ste."

And Bud Selig was the former Commissioner of Major League Baseball (MLB), who was later inducted into their Hall of Fame (located in Cooperstown, NY).  "In Cooperstown" is American shorthand for "in the Baseball Hall of Fame."

@Tony R Fr. in the Holy Women clue is short for French, indicating that we want an abbreviation for the answer, and STE is short for the feminine form of the French word for saint. SELIG, it seems safe to assume, is Bud's last name: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Selig. And Cooperstown is the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame.
